name: Privatebin.txt - What is Privatebin?
description: PrivateBin is an open-source, web-based application that allows users to securely share text, code snippets, or other sensitive information without revealing the content to the server. It provides encryption for the data being shared, ensuring that only the intended recipients with the correct password can access the information. This tool is useful for sharing confidential data or collaborating on sensitive projects without compromising privacy.
use_cases: Sharing code snippets or text documents securely
Collaborating on sensitive projects or content
Sharing confidential information with specific individuals
Protecting sensitive data from unauthorized access
capabilities: Zero knowledge of pasted data on the server

name: Privatebin.txt - Why should I use PrivateBin?
description: This section explains the benefits of using PrivateBin for both users and server administrators. For users, it provides a secure way to share sensitive information like passwords with others, choose a trusted provider, and discuss topics privately. For server administrators, it protects them from legal orders to scan user content since they don't have access to the encryption keys, and allows customization of the open-source code and templates.
use_cases: Sharing sensitive information like passwords securely
Choosing a trusted provider for hosting the service
Discussing topics privately with others
Protecting against legal orders to scan user content (for server admins)

name: Privatebin.txt - Features
description: This section outlines the various features and capabilities of Privatebin.txt, which appears to be a secure and private online platform for sharing text or code snippets. It allows users to create password-protected pastes, set expiration times, format content with Markdown, highlight code syntax, and choose from different visual themes. The platform also supports encryption, anonymous discussions, API integration, language selection, QR code generation, and automatic purging of old pastes.
use_cases: Securely sharing sensitive information or code snippets
Collaborating on text or code with others anonymously
Temporarily storing text or code snippets with expiration options
Integrating with other applications via API

name: Privatebin.txt - Where is it currently being used?
description: This section explains that Privatebin is currently being used to securely share sensitive information, such as AWS first-time passwords and IAM secret keys, with users via email. Privatebin exposes an API that allows the creation of temporary, encrypted pastes, and returns a unique URL (hashUrl) for accessing the paste. This URL is then shared with users over email, enabling them to securely access the sensitive information without the risk of interception or unauthorized access.
use_cases: Sharing AWS first-time passwords with users via email
Automatic rotation of IAM secret keys and sharing new key pairs with users via email
Secure sharing of sensitive information with authorized users
capabilities: Generates unique hashUrl for accessing pastes
Secure sharing of sensitive information via email
Automatic rotation and sharing of IAM secret keys

name: Privatebin.txt - How does it work?
description: This section explains how the data is encrypted and decrypted in the browser using a strong encryption algorithm called AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) with a 256-bit key length and a mode called Galois Counter mode. This ensures that the data is securely transmitted and stored, protecting the privacy and confidentiality of the information. The image provided illustrates the encryption process visually.
use_cases: Secure data transmission
Protecting sensitive information
Ensuring privacy and confidentiality
Compliance with data protection regulations
capabilities: Visual representation of the encryption process

name: Privatebin.txt - What parts are or aren't encrypted in a paste?
description: This section explains what parts of a paste (text, comments, usernames) are encrypted end-to-end in the browser before uploading and after downloading, and what metadata (timestamps, expiration time, format, IP-based user icon) is not encrypted. It also clarifies that the decryption key is part of the URL and the password is not stored or transmitted. The section mentions that pastes are stored in a PostgreSQL database to support high scale.
use_cases: Securely sharing sensitive text or code snippets
Enabling discussions on shared pastes with encrypted comments
Allowing users to set expiration times for pastes
Storing and retrieving pastes in a scalable database
capabilities: End-to-end encryption of paste text, usernames, and comments
Non-encryption of metadata like timestamps, expiration time, and paste format
Paste storage in a PostgreSQL database for scalability
Support for plain text, source code, and markdown paste formats
Option to enable or disable discussions on pastes
